title: 105_s2479
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Commission on the Advancement of Women and Minorities in Science, Engineering, and Technology Development Act". Congress finds that women, minorities, and persons with disabilities in science and engineering face underrepresentation and barriers in education and employment. Progress has been made, but there is still room for improvement in increasing participation and opportunities in these fields. Women in science and engineering face challenges such as underrepresentation in the labor force, lower likelihood of full-time employment in their field, and disparities in salary compared to men. Additionally, women are more likely to be employed at 2-year institutions and teach part-time. Minority groups like Blacks, Hispanics, and Native Americans are also underrepresented in graduate science and engineering programs. Blacks, Hispanics, and Native Americans make up 23% of the US population but only 6% are scientists or engineers. Women face hurdles in accessing industrial jobs in science and engineering, including limited access and common recruitment practices that overlook them. Paternalism, sexual harassment, and discrimination are challenges women often encounter in these fields. Women in science and engineering face discrimination, lower salaries compared to men, inequitable job assignments, and limited opportunities for advancement into management positions. A commission is proposed to address these issues and eliminate barriers to recruitment. The proposed commission aims to eliminate barriers for women and minorities in science, engineering, and technology fields by promoting workforce diversity, sensitizing employers to the need for recruitment and retention, and encouraging replication of successful programs. A commission called the "Commission on the Advancement of Women and Minorities in Science, Engineering, and Technology Development" is established to promote diversity and eliminate barriers in these fields. The Commission will review research and may conduct additional research to identify the representation of women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science, engineering, and technology occupations, assess their readiness for careers and advancement, and examine employer and union practices related to their recruitment, retention, and progression in these fields. The Commission will review research and may conduct additional research to identify the representation of women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science, engineering, and technology occupations, assess their readiness for careers and advancement, and examine employer and union practices related to their recruitment, retention, and progression in these fields. The Commission aims to identify opportunities and barriers for the recruitment, retention, and advancement of underrepresented groups in science, engineering, and technology, and issue recommendations for lawful policies that government, academia, and private industry can follow. The Commission aims to identify opportunities and barriers for the recruitment, retention, and advancement of underrepresented groups in science, engineering, and technology. This includes identifying disincentives for women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in graduate education and undergraduate programs, as well as reasons for their disproportionate departure from these fields before completing their education. The Commission aims to assess the implementation of recommendations for women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science and technology fields. This includes compiling federally funded reports on encouraging and retaining these groups in the workforce. The Commission will assess the implementation of recommendations for women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science and technology fields. This includes evaluating the benefits of family-friendly policies to support recruiting, retaining, and advancing women in these fields. SEC. 5. MEMBERSHIP. The Commission shall consist of 11 members appointed by various officials, including the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, majority leader of the Senate, minority leader of the Senate, and Chairman of the National Governors Association. Members will be selected from for-profit entities hiring in engineering, science, or technology, as well as individuals in education or academia in life science, physical science, or engineering fields. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various officials, including the Vice Chairman of the National Governors Association. Initial appointments must be made within 90 days of the Act's enactment, with members serving for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. Members do not receive payment but are reimbursed for travel expenses. A majority of members constitutes a quorum. The Commission consists of 11 members appointed by various officials, with a majority needed for a quorum. The Chairperson is elected by the members, and the Commission must meet at least 5 times for the report. Members are not considered federal employees except for specific purposes related to compensation and tort claims. SEC. 6. DIRECTOR AND STAFF OF COMMISSION; EXPERTS AND CONSULTANTS. The Commission appoints a Director paid at a specified rate and may hire additional staff. The Director and staff can be appointed without following certain civil service laws and pay regulations. The Commission is also allowed to hire experts and consultants as needed. The Commission can hire experts and consultants under specific pay regulations and may request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in its duties. The Commission has the power to hire experts and consultants and may request personnel from Federal agencies to assist in its duties. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence as needed. Members and agents can take actions authorized by the Commission. The Commission can obtain information from US departments or agencies and use the US mails for official purposes. The Commission has the authority to conduct hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. The Administrator of General Services will provide administrative support services upon request. The Commission may contract with government or private agencies for research purposes. The Commission will submit a report with findings and recommendations to the President, Congress, and State officials. The Act does not require non-Federal entities to provide personnel information, and any information obtained cannot be used in employment litigation. The Commission's access to information will terminate after a certain period. SEC. 10. TERMINATION; ACCESS TO INFORMATION.

The Commission will terminate 30 days after submitting the required report. Before termination, the Commission will provide gathered information to the National Science Foundation for public access. The Foundation will serve as a central repository and make the information available online.

SEC. 11. REVIEW OF INFORMATION PROVIDED BY THE NATIONAL SCIENCE FOUNDATION AND OTHER AGENCIES. The Commission can request information from the National Science Foundation and other Federal agencies on academic degrees awarded to women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science, engineering, and technology fields, as well as workforce representation and retention. The Commission will also review information gathered by the National Science Foundation for its biennial report on Women, Minorities, and Persons with Disabilities in Science and Engineering. The Commission will review information provided on academic degrees awarded to women, minorities, and individuals with disabilities in science, engineering, and technology fields. Recommendations will be made to correct deficiencies in data collection and analysis that may hinder understanding factors affecting their attraction and retention. Additionally, an assessment of the National Science Foundation's biennial report on the same groups will be conducted with suggestions for improvement. The term "State" in this Act includes several States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the Northern Mariana Islands, American Samoa, Guam, the Virgin Islands, and other US territories. Authorization of appropriations includes $400,000 for fiscal year 1999 and $400,000 for fiscal year 2000.
